audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female voice introducing Douglas Walker, mentioning his background in advertising, his published work, and his reputation as an authority on a subject that "doesn't matter at all," in a slightly humorous tone. As she finishes the introduction, applause erupts. Following the applause, a male voice says "Hello" in a normal speaking tone, and a dog barks.

The audio clip begins with a man giving a presentation, beginning with a bit of humor to introduce his topic of "rock," which he equates to a "closed fist powering down on a poorly chosen pair of scissors." He becomes more serious as he shares how rock paper scissors consumed a third of his attention for a decade. He shares a memory of a particularly intense rock paper scissors match with his brother at his parents' cottage, which eventually led to the creation of "The World Rock Paper Scissors Society."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker beginning a presentation, remarking with a humorous tone about a back-story he and his company developed. He then explains that he was left with the notion that there seemed to be more to the game than he initially thought and started a website, followed by a comment about what websites used to look like. The speaker defines gambits, relating them to rock, paper, scissors, and continues to describe how the game doesn’t leave much of a trace in anthropological records so they created the culture and history of rock, paper, scissors without the constraints of facts. He continues by noting that they took a lot of inspiration from communist and cultural revolution imagery, because people always had their fists out with the labor movement, speaking in a clear, informative tone throughout, frequently interrupted by laughter from an audience.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing an event, mentioning it "meant a lot to us" and worked "really, really well" for the movement. He notes selling memberships and merchandise, leading to the creation of the "Goddamn World Championships of Rock Paper Scissors." The speaker describes the intensity of the game and the event's popularity, referencing CBS, ABC, and BBC fighting for pictures of "Master Rochambeau," the "Michael Jordan of the sport." Light music then plays in the background.

The audio clip consists of a stand-up comedy performance, featuring a male speaker recounting humorous anecdotes about Rock Paper Scissors. He describes how they exaggerated someone's importance to the media, the publication of an official strategy guide, and a documentary that won an award at Slamdance. The speaker jokingly shares that other countries began sending their champions and mentions how the ego of a Rock Paper Scissors champion is unbelievable. He said one of the hardest decisions he ever had to make was deciding whether Fox or ESPN should get the television rights. He also adds that Rock Paper Scissors is not as good of a televised sport as you might think it is. He speaks in an energetic and humorous tone, pausing for audience laughter. The general ambient noise in the background suggests a live audience.

The audio clip features a male speaker who starts by referring to a past event he’s glad did not happen again. He then transitions to discussing a 2008 Guinness World Record achievement—winning the largest rock paper scissors competition—noting the contrast between his inner child’s excitement and his adult self’s perception that "Guinness has really jumped the shark." The speaker's tone is generally casual, with moments of humor.

The audio clip features a male speaker recounting an interesting story. He begins by noting that a Japanese gentleman sold an art collection worth approximately $20 million featuring famous artists. Unable to decide which auction house to use, he settled it with "Rock, Paper, Scissors". The speaker emphasizes that this was "the largest, most expensive Rock, Paper, Scissors match in history of $12 million".

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing a game that might seem like chance, but actually involves "two people making an active decision". He emphasizes that people are subject to it and that data from thousands of matches supports his point. He mentions that rock is the most frequent choice and that players tend to shy away from scissors.

The audio clip features a male speaker on stage, who initially states he's leaving the audience with "one final thought". He introduces a "top 7 rock paper scissors strategist" named C. Barns, sharing Barns's quote: "Paper is the answer, should rock be the question?" This is said with emphasis, and the speaker concludes by thanking the audience. Immediately following, there is loud applause, conveying appreciation for the speech.
